awd_titl_txt: Investigating Corneal Biomechanics after Collagen Cross-linking
awd_abstract_narration:
The cornea is a transparent dome-shaped tissue at the front of the eye that allows light rays to enter the eye.  The mechanical properties of the cornea play an important role in maintaining its stability and optical function. The loss of corneal structural integrity because of ophthalmic diseases such as keratoconus and ectasia leads to significant bulging and may cause severe visual impairment including blindness. Corneal collagen crosslinking using riboflavin and ultraviolet-A (UVA) light is a recent treatment procedure that restores corneal mechanics and halts the progression of irregular changes in its shape. Nevertheless, despite promising experimental and clinical data, its underlying mechanisms are still unknown. In this research, an integrated experimental and computational framework will be used to characterize the effects of the collagen crosslinking procedure on different aspects of corneal biomechanical properties.  The deeper fundamental understanding of strengthening effects of this minimally invasive procedure could lead to significant improvement of its performance and effectiveness.

This project will provide novel insight into the underlying mechanisms of corneal collagen crosslinking therapy and will assess its efficacy in restoring the mechanical strength of the cornea. To this end, different in vitro experimental techniques will be used to measure the changes in the mechanical properties of corneal tissue after collagen crosslinking using riboflavin and UVA. These experiments will be complemented by a numerical finite element model based on mixture theory. From the mechanics point of view, the corneal stroma will be modelled as a composite material consisting of a ground substance and reinforcing collagen fibrils. In addition to the significant contribution of this project to the existing body of research on the cornea, its successful completion will have a broader impact and may eventually lead to new engineering design concepts.  Finally, this project includes a number of educational activities. The primary objectives of these efforts are to attract students in STEM fields and train/engage both undergraduate and graduate students in biomechanics. It is expected that this project, with its blend of biology and mechanics, will motivate students to participate in engineering research by helping them better appreciate the connection between science, biology, and engineering.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The research objective of this project was to investigate the effects of corneal collagen crosslinking (CXL) procedure on the mechanical behavior of the cornea. The cornea is a clear connective tissue serving as the principle refractive element of the eye. The crosslinking of the corneal tissue is a therapeutic treatment option to slow down the progression of Keratoconus. The CXL procedure enhances corneal rigidity by creating crosslinks within its extracellular matrix. This project investigated the effects of the CXL procedure on corneal mechanical properties. The most significant findings are as follows.

We quantified the mechanical property improvement of the CXL procedure as a function of hydration by conducting uniaxial tensile experiments. It is desirable to swell cornea prior to the CXL therapy in order to prevent possible endothelial damage, especially in individuals with thin cornea. This project investigated how corneal artificial swelling would affect the stiffening effects of the CXL treatment. In particular, the concentration of dextran in riboflavin solution was varied in order to crosslink porcine corneal samples at different hydration. The amount of stiffening was inversely proportional to sample hydration prior to the CXL treatment. Furthermore, corneal tensile properties increased with decreasing hydration. In order to better characterize the effects of hydration and CXL procedure on the corneal mechanical response, we crosslinked samples at different hydration and measured their mechanical properties at the same hydration. These experiments showed that swelling corneal samples prior to the CXL treatment would not significantly affect the amount of their biomechanical improvement. This observation was discussed in terms of the existing differences in the microstructure and mechanics of anterior and posterior layers of the cornea. We excised anterior and posterior corneal flaps from full thickness corneas and crosslinked them at different hydration levels. An inverse relation between the hydration and the average tensile properties of anterior and posterior flaps was found. Furthermore, anterior flaps showed significantly stiffer response than posterior flaps. The CXL procedure increased significantly the tensile stiffness of anterior samples but did not have any significant effect on tensile properties of posterior flaps. Based on these observations, it was suggested that significant interweaving of collagen lamellae in the anterior region was a detrimental factor for the effectiveness of the CXL treatment. Similar experiments were performed on the human donor tissue in order to compare the mechanical response of human donor and porcine cadaver specimens. Finally, computational models were created for the constitutive response of the cornea by incorporating the three-dimensional collagen fiber orientation. 

This project created new knowledge for better understanding the stiffening effects of the CXL treatment. A deeper understanding of how different organizations of collagen fibers throughout the thickness influence the macroscopic properties of the cornea may guide future scientific efforts for finding new therapeutic options for Keratoconus.  The research outcomes of this project appeared in a number of peer-reviewed journal publications. Furthermore, several presentations were given at the national and international conferences and meetings. This project supported graduate and undergraduate students. Furthermore, it allowed us to host young students in the research laboratory in order to encourage their participation in STEM disciplines. 

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2023
Modified by: Hamed Hatami-Marbini
